meaning_mnemonic:
The <kanji>remainder</kanji> <kanji>product</kanji>s are the things that haven't been sold. They're the <vocabulary>unsold merchandise</vocabulary>. They're the <vocabulary>remaining stock</vocabulary>.

This is a very specific word that is mainly used in the context of inventory management or retail sales.

We all <kanji>build</kanji> up something in <kanji>front</kanji> of ourselves. It's the front we present to the world, the <vocabulary>public behavior</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>public stance</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>social niceties</vocabulary> that maintain harmony.

建前 is very important in Japan. For example, you might find yourself invited to an acquaintance's home out of courtesy, with the expectation that you’ll decline (also out of courtesy!). A host of a party may say "just bring yourself," but guests know this could be 建前, and considering their own 建前, they bring a small gift anyways.  People can also be reluctant to say "no" to things, like drinks with coworkers when they really want to go home, and may not to show it when they find situations inconvenient or unpleasant. So you might need some guesswork to peek behind the 建前 that people build up in front of themselves!

You have <kanji>prosper</kanji>ed so much that <kanji>light</kanji> seems to shine forth from your every pore in a golden aura. With the wealth, fame, and admiration you have achieved, you are the walking embodiment of <vocabulary>glory</vocabulary>.

栄光 is commonly used in expressions like 過去の栄光 (past glory), referring to the great achievements or status that one had in the past.

You've <kanji>take</kanji>n a <kanji>decision</kanji> from someone. By doing this, you've created a kind of <vocabulary>arrangement</vocabulary> with them. Imagine yourself pulling this decision out of the person. They don't want to necessarily give it to you, but they're letting you pull it out of them, kind of. When you've pulled it out, you've come to an arrangement, though they've pulled some of your decision out too.

When you <kanji>divide</kanji> and <kanji>untie</kanji> things, you're unraveling the connections between them. In other words, you're doing a <vocabulary>breakdown</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>dismantling</vocabulary> of something.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>give</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to give</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to grant</vocabulary>.

This is a relatively formal word that is generally used in writing. In conversations, people commonly use more relaxed words like あげる or くれる.

Quite the <kanji>scene</kanji>, this <kanji>view</kanji> is. So what you're looking at is a <vocabulary>landscape</vocabulary>. This often refers to a <vocabulary>cityscape</vocabulary> or the general <vocabulary>scenery</vocabulary> of an area.

This is a formal word that’s commonly used in the context of urban planning or environmental design.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>belong</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to belong to</vocabulary>.

属する is a formal term for describing someone or something’s belonging to or being part of a group, category or classification.

For <kanji>year</kanji>s and years, your <kanji>comrade</kanji>s have been with you, but now they're all <vocabulary>elderly</vocabulary>.

This is a less common version of 年配, but you'll still sometimes encounter it.
The <kanji>next month</kanji> (来月) isn't enough... one more next month, please. Let's do it <kanji>again</kanji>. That month is the <vocabulary>month after next</vocabulary>.
You have <kanji>next year</kanji> (来年), but then you do a year <kanji>again</kanji>. That's the <vocabulary>year after next</vocabulary>.

When a 限定 (limit) is applied to 販売 (selling), it’s a sort of <vocabulary>exclusive sale</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>limited offer</vocabulary>.

限定販売 is a sales strategy where companies limit the availability of their products to certain regions, stores, time frames, or club members.
You learned that 抜ける is "to fall out." If your <kanji>waist</kanji> falls out, you can't remain standing. You have to curl up on the ground, like a <vocabulary>coward</vocabulary>.

Remember how 抜く means "to pull something out"? 抜ける describes something coming out of where it was, so it means <vocabulary>to come out</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to fall out</vocabulary>. 

This can be used for air coming out of a balloon, hair falling out, or pages missing from a book. It also means passing through places or leaving a group you were a part of.

To distinguish this word from 抜く, imagine a bunch of <reading>kale</reading> (ける) coming out of the ground on its own! Nobody pulled it out, it just came out by itself.

The kanji itself means <kanji>catch</kanji>, and 捕える means <vocabulary>to capture something</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to catch something</vocabulary>. 

捕える is often used in writing to describe having someone captured to keep them from escaping. But it can also be used in more abstract contexts, like capturing a moment in a photograph, grasping a concept or idea, or seizing an opportunity.

You can remember the meaning for this because everyone wants to capture <reading>el</reading>ves (える). Sorry, elves… You're just so cool, people want to capture and keep you forever.

Remember how 掛ける is "to hang something"? Well, 掛かる focuses on the fact that something is hanging, without specifying who did it. So it means <vocabulary>to be hung</vocabulary>. Use it to say a picture is hung on the wall, for example. 

掛かる can also mean <vocabulary>to be hooked</vocabulary>, whether it's the picture hooked to the wall or a fish that happens <vocabulary>to be caught</vocabulary> on a hook. 

These uses are all intransitive, so you don't need a direct object them. A hint for this is that 掛かる ends with okurigana that rhyme with ある, and those kinds of verbs tend to be intransitive.

隠す is "to hide something." 隠れる is <vocabulary>to hide oneself</vocabulary> or just <vocabulary>to hide</vocabulary>. You know this because when someone is hiding, it's <reading>rare</reading> (れる) for anyone else to find them. They take this hide-and-seek thing pretty seriously, you know!

This word can also mean <vocabulary>to be hidden</vocabulary> because sometimes the subject is an inanimate object, as in 月が雲に隠れる (the moon is hidden in the cloud).

The <kanji>value</kanji> is in various <kanji>steps</kanji>. Each step is a different amount, and each amount is a <vocabulary>price</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>cost</vocabulary>.

値段 refers to the price attached to something you can buy, like in stores or markets. For example, you could use 値段 to ask how much something costs at a shop or when talking about the price of a particular meal.
You're so <kanji>healthy</kanji> it puts you at <kanji>ease</kanji>. That's your <vocabulary>health</vocabulary>! So healthful, go you!

A <kanji>healthy</kanji> bit of <kanji>forget</kanji>ting <kanji>symptom</kanji>s means you might have <vocabulary>amnesia</vocabulary>.

健忘症 often refers to short-term <vocabulary>memory loss</vocabulary>, either full or partial, but some people might also use it in a sort of joking way for everyday <vocabulary>forgetfulness</vocabulary>.
Remember how 効果 means "effect"? Add <kanji>~like</kanji> to that and it's <vocabulary>effective</vocabulary>!
<kanji>Getting a position</kanji> of <kanji>employment</kanji> means <vocabulary>finding employment</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>getting a job</vocabulary>.

When you <kanji>get a position</kanji> in some <kanji>business</kanji>, you’re considered <vocabulary>working</vocabulary>.

就業 is a formal word that can refer to both <vocabulary>being employed</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>being at work</vocabulary> for the day. It’s commonly used in kanji compounds, such as 就業時間 (working hours) and 就業規則 (employment regulations).

I <kanji>retreat</kanji>! I <kanji>yield</kanji>! I can't take it anymore, it's so <vocabulary>boring</vocabulary>. Just imagine yourself giving up on whatever you're doing because you're so darn bored. You can't stand it. You have to retreat. You are ready to yield. Booooooring.

巻く is "to roll." ずし is すし. This is <vocabulary>rolled sushi</vocabulary>.

Makizushi refers to cylindrical rolled sushi, which is commonly served in bite-sized pieces. If it's shaped like a cone, it's known as 手巻きずし (temakizushi).
巻く is "to roll up." If you roll up spring, you get a roll that's spring flavored. These are known as <vocabulary>spring rolls</vocabulary>.

Remember 頑張る means “to persevere” or “to do one’s best”? This time you're telling someone to 頑張る, so this word means something like <vocabulary>do your best</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>hang in there</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>good luck</vocabulary>! Speaking of which, 頑張れ, you!
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>angry</kanji>, the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to get angry</vocabulary>.

An <kanji>angry</kanji> <kanji>chirp</kanji> is a type of shout. The verb version is <vocabulary>to yell</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to shout</vocabulary>.

怒鳴る suggests anger, as you can tell from the kanji, so it's used when someone yells or shouts to scold others or to express anger or frustration.
This is the noun version of <kanji>worry</kanji>, making it <vocabulary>a worry</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>a trouble</vocabulary>.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>worry</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to worry</vocabulary>.

悩む is often intransitive, like 彼はいつも悩んでいる (he's always worrying). But it can also be transitive, in which case it'll take a direct object, like 彼女のことを悩む (to worry about her).

You've been led <kanji>astray</kanji> and you've been <kanji>misguided</kanji>. What a <vocabulary>trouble</vocabulary>, and indeed a <vocabulary>troublesome</vocabulary> <vocabulary>inconvenience</vocabulary> all this is.

迷惑 refers to a <vocabulary>nuisance</vocabulary> that bothers others, like trimming your toenails or speaking loudly on the phone in public.

You're being <kanji>invited</kanji>, but you're also being <kanji>misguided</kanji>. This is <vocabulary>seduction</vocabulary> that's talking. A misguided invitation is never a good thing!

This word also translates to <vocabulary>temptation</vocabulary>, but keep in mind that 誘惑’s focus is more on an external factor that entices someone into succumbing to temptation.

You know 抜く means "to pull something out." Whenever you <kanji>see</kanji> something and pull something out of it, you're able <vocabulary>to see something's true nature</vocabulary>. You're able <vocabulary>to see through</vocabulary> things like situations, lies, and people.

見抜く often suggests figuring something out instinctively, with sharp insight or keen perception, especially when it comes to understanding the essence or true nature of something.

You learned that 抜ける is "to fall out." If an <kanji>interval of time</kanji> falls out of you, you're totally spaced out. You won't learn anything and you'll become an <vocabulary>idiot</vocabulary>.

間抜け can refer to both a person who does something foolish and to the foolish actions themselves. It's often used to criticize <vocabulary>dumb</vocabulary> behavior.

You know 抜く means "to pull something out" and 出す means "to remove," so this word also means <vocabulary>to pull something out</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to extract</vocabulary>.

More specifically, 抜き出す means to pull something out from a larger set of something. For example, this could mean taking a single bill out of your wallet, or selecting specific data from a large dataset.

You <kanji>beckon</kanji> someone to come to you, but then you <kanji>wait</kanji>. This is because they aren't really near you, so your beckon is more like an invitation. That's why this word means <vocabulary>to invite</vocabulary> .

招待する is a formal word for inviting someone, particularly to formal events or places.

You learned that 掛かる can mean "to be hooked." If you're doing something physical like climbing and your <kanji>hand</kanji> hooks onto something, that thing is called a <vocabulary>handhold</vocabulary>.

Figuratively, this can also mean <vocabulary>clue</vocabulary>, since a clue is something you grasp onto, much like a handhold, to help you progress in solving a crime or mystery. This figurative use of 手掛かり is actually the most common!
<kanji>Ascend</kanji> and <kanji>advance</kanji>! Congratulations, you ascend and advance by getting a new <vocabulary>job promotion</vocabulary>.

The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

暇 means the <vocabulary>spare time</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>free time</vocabulary> you have when you're <vocabulary>not busy</vocabulary> with work, school, or other obligations. It can also indicate a slow period for a business or a time when you have nothing to do, often suggesting a sense of boredom.

The <kanji>spare time</kanji> is your <vocabulary>vacation</vocabulary>. It is your <vocabulary>holiday</vocabulary>.

休暇 is a relatively formal word that commonly refers to <vocabulary>time off</vocabulary> from work, ranging from a day off to seasonal vacation to temporary leave.

Coins? Bills? <kanji>Both</kanji> can be <kanji>replace</kanji>d if you want to <vocabulary>change money</vocabulary> at this <vocabulary>money exchange</vocabulary>. Just don’t do your <vocabulary>currency exchange</vocabulary> at the airport — the rates aren’t so great.

You'll probably see this word the most in arcades where you can go to the 両替 machine and get coins to feed your crane game addiction.

<kanji>Take</kanji> and <kanji>replace</kanji> something. That is <vocabulary>to replace</vocabulary> something with something else.

取り替える generally means <vocabulary>to swap out</vocabulary> something with a new or different item of the same kind, like replacing an old gas meter with a new one, or exchanging books with your friend after you've both read your own.
You know how 替える is "to replace"? Well, you're replacing what you <kanji>wear</kanji>. That's a <vocabulary>change of clothes</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>spare clothes</vocabulary>.

You are trying to <kanji>research</kanji> the <kanji>extreme</kanji>s. If you do that, you'll be able to figure out the <vocabulary>ultimate</vocabulary> weapon. Just researching the safe middle-ground stuff won't get you ultimate. Extreme research, however, will.
The <kanji>south</kanji>ern <kanji>extreme</kanji> is the <vocabulary>South Pole</vocabulary>, aka the <vocabulary>Antarctic</vocabulary>. It's about as south as you can go.

結構 is something like "fine" or "alright." This is just a little more polite. You can use this to say <vocabulary>no thank you</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>I'm fine</vocabulary> to someone trying to offer you something.

Remember how 構う is "to care about"? You can convert it into お構いなく to politely tell someone not to care about you. So this means, <vocabulary>don't mind me</vocabulary>.

It can also mean <vocabulary>without regard for</vocabulary>, especially when someone keeps doing something without caring about other people, their surroundings, or unfavorable conditions.
Remember how 規模 is <kanji>scale</kanji>? Well, this is a big scale, which is on a <vocabulary>large scale</vocabulary>.
規模 is "scale." This is a <kanji>small</kanji> one, making this <vocabulary>small scale</vocabulary>.

To get to another <kanji>floor</kanji> you have to go up one <kanji>step</kanji>, then another, and another… These are <vocabulary>stairs</vocabulary>. The word you're looking for is stairs! Do you have any 階段 in your house?

<kanji>Step</kanji> by <kanji>step</kanji>. If you take things step by step, you're moving up <vocabulary>gradually</vocabulary>, taking <vocabulary>steps</vocabulary>.

段々 is often used to describe gradual progress. But sometimes you'll see it used for terraced fields or buildings too, since they sorta resemble steps!

Each time you take a <kanji>step</kanji> up, you reach a new <kanji>floor</kanji>… a new <vocabulary>stage</vocabulary>! We're talking metaphorical stages. You're making all kinds of progress. The first stage, the second stage. The third <vocabulary>phase</vocabulary>. Man, you're blowing through all the stages and phases of Japanese learning. Keep it up!
第一 means "the first," and 段 is a <kanji>step</kanji>. So, this is <vocabulary>the first step</vocabulary>.

This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning it's probably an adjective. The kanji means <kanji>dense</kanji>, and this can also mean <vocabulary>dense</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>thick</vocabulary> in some contexts, like if you’re describing fog, or body hair! More generally, it can be used for anything that’s highly concentrated, so you can use it for things like <vocabulary>deep</vocabulary> colors, or <vocabulary>strong</vocabulary> coffee too!
When something is <kanji>dense</kanji> to a certain <kanji>degree</kanji>, you’re talking about the <vocabulary>density</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>concentration</vocabulary> of something.

Multiple <kanji>symptom</kanji>s combine to make a <vocabulary>syndrome</vocabulary>. If you see this at the end of a word, you know it means "______ syndrome," or else indicates some kind of health condition.  

〜症 is used in medical terms for certain health conditions, symptoms, or syndromes, like 熱中症 (heatstroke) or 認知症 (dementia).
Your <kanji>symptom</kanji> <kanji>condition</kanji> is your <vocabulary>symptom</vocabulary>s that you have.
The <kanji>not</kanji> <kanji>sleep</kanji> <kanji>symptom</kanji> shows you have a disorder that involves not sleeping. That is <vocabulary>insomnia</vocabulary>.

This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>pain</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>painful</vocabulary>. 

痛い is commonly used to say that some part of the body hurts or feels sore.
<kanji>Head</kanji> <kanji>pain</kanji> is when you have a <vocabulary>headache</vocabulary>.
This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>sleep</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>sleepy</vocabulary>.
Feeling <kanji>drowsy</kanji> and like I want to <kanji>sleep</kanji>. I just want to <vocabulary>sleep</vocabulary> so bad.

The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. This refers to a literal edge, not a figurative one.

端 refers to the <vocabulary>edge</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>end</vocabulary> of something, like the edge of a table, the far end of a bridge, or even the <vocabulary>corner</vocabulary> of a page.

The <kanji>previous</kanji> (or <kanji>ahead</kanji>) <kanji>edge</kanji> is the <vocabulary>tip</vocabulary> of something, like your finger or your chopsticks. It's also a word used to describe <vocabulary>the latest</vocabulary> (technology, etc), because it's on the <vocabulary>cutting edge</vocabulary>. The tip!

Take the <kanji>middle</kanji> <kanji>route</kanji>, <kanji>half</kanji> to the <kanji>edge</kanji>. You don't do anything the full way. Just to the middle. Just to the half. Not to the edge. This was really <vocabulary>half finished</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>half assed</vocabulary> of you.

At the <kanji>extreme</kanji> <kanji>edge</kanji>, which is just the <vocabulary>extreme</vocabulary>.

極端 means something is taken to the extreme without moderation, so it generally has a negative connotation.

If you can <kanji>offer</kanji> a <kanji>salary</kanji> to someone, it means you've got plenty of <vocabulary>supply</vocabulary>. The bigger the salary you can offer, the bigger your supply is, probably. That's why those big tech companies can pay so well — they have an endless supply of paying customers or ad revenue, I guess. 

供給 is a somewhat formal word you'd generally hear in the context of economics — like <vocabulary>supplying</vocabulary> goods, energy, or food where there's demand. You wouldn't use it for art supplies or the food you buy every day.

When you <kanji>ascend</kanji> in <kanji>salary</kanji> you get a <vocabulary>pay raise</vocabulary> at work.

Note that this is a relatively formal word to talk about <vocabulary>getting a raise</vocabulary>.

When you <kanji>tighten</kanji> things up and <kanji>bind</kanji> things together, it's hard to separate them again. That's why this word is used <vocabulary>to conclude</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to enter into</vocabulary> important agreements, like treaties and contracts.

Note that this word is quite formal, which makes sense, given the contexts it’s usually used in.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>tighten</kanji> so the verb vocab version means <vocabulary>to tighten</vocabulary>, like a screw, or to tie, like a necktie or towel.

締める can also mean <vocabulary>to wrap up</vocabulary> when used in reference to a speech or some other occasion. In Japanese culture, people often 締める a situation with some shared action, like clapping in rhythm to end a celebration or having a final bowl of ramen to close out a night. You call it 締める because it's like you're tying off the event and giving it a sense of closure.
A <kanji>group</kanji> that's <kanji>weave</kanji>d together so tightly with hierarchy and everything else is a little more complicated than a group. It's an <vocabulary>organization</vocabulary>.
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>weave</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to weave</vocabulary>.

When your <kanji>stomach</kanji> <kanji>hurts</kanji> you have yourself a little <vocabulary>stomachache</vocabulary>.

Try to remember this isn't for general abdominal pain. 胃痛 is specifically for pain or discomfort in the stomach (the internal organ) — a literal stomachache.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

When you <kanji>cut</kanji> your <kanji>abdomen</kanji> you are committing <vocabulary>seppuku</vocabulary>. It will help if you already know the word "seppuku" from English, since it's also the reading here.

切腹 is a form of <vocabulary>ritual suicide</vocabulary> by self-inflicted disembowelment, often performed by samurai to restore honor.
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>visit</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to visit</vocabulary>.

A <kanji>visit</kanji> <kanji>problem</kanji> is when someone makes <vocabulary>a visit</vocabulary>, because you're the type of person who doesn't like visitors, since they're usually so inconsiderate and you have to feed them. That's why <vocabulary>a visit</vocabulary> is a visit problem.
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>lend</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to lend</vocabulary>.

The <kanji>lend</kanji>ing gets <kanji>cut</kanji> right away when you make a <vocabulary>private reservation</vocabulary>.

貸し切り means reserving a space exclusively, like renting out a restaurant for a birthday party or chartering a bus, cruise, or jet.

auxiliary_meanings.meaning: To Be Just Around The Corner

meaning_mnemonic:
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>urge</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to urge</vocabulary>.

At its core, 迫る means <vocabulary>to approach</vocabulary>, like a deadline or danger drawing near. This idea extends to urging someone because it's like you're coming really close to them, <vocabulary>to press</vocabulary> them into action.

The <kanji>pressure</kanji> is <kanji>urge</kanji>d upon you. It's the <vocabulary>pressure</vocabulary>, so much pressure!

圧迫 refers to a tight pressure caused by strong compression, or to the act of pressing down itself. Figuratively, it can also mean <vocabulary>constriction</vocabulary>, like tuition fees putting a strain on a household budget, or <vocabulary>oppression</vocabulary>, such as people being subjugated.

Someone has an <kanji>urge</kanji> to <kanji>damage</kanji> things. If that person wants to harm you, you might be facing <vocabulary>persecution</vocabulary>.

As you might guess, this word is quite formal.

We're <kanji>cut</kanji> right down to the end, reaching that <kanji>urge</kanji> position where <vocabulary>urgency</vocabulary> is so strong.

切迫 is used to describe the tension in a situation where a time limit is <vocabulary>drawing near</vocabulary>, or to describe something bad or dangerous as <vocabulary>impending</vocabulary>.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>astray</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to go astray</vocabulary> (because you don't just "to astray" now do you?). You can use it if you ever happen <vocabulary>to get lost</vocabulary>. 

Beyond physically getting lost, 迷う is also for times when you waver between different choices or hesitate to take a decisive step.

After going <kanji>astray</kanji>, the <kanji>child</kanji> becomes a <vocabulary>lost child</vocabulary>. Let's help them find their way home.

Keep in mind that 迷子 isn't only for lost children; it applies to anyone who's lost, such as a <vocabulary>lost person</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>stray animal</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>road</kanji> where you're <kanji>astray</kanji> is a road that goes all around in different ways, tricking you and making you lost. This is a <vocabulary>maze</vocabulary>.
Led <kanji>astray</kanji> in what you <kanji>believe</kanji> by all these <vocabulary>superstition</vocabulary>s. These superstitions will lead you astray, don't believe them!

auxiliary_meanings.meaning: To Be Out Of The Hospital
To Get Out Of The Hospital
To Be Discharged From The Hospital
To Get Discharged From The Hospital
To Be Released From The Hospital
To Get Released From The Hospital

meaning_mnemonic: Time to <kanji>retreat</kanji> from the <kanji>institution</kanji>. Basically, you are leaving an institution, particularly institutions like hospitals, asylums, etc. When you are leaving one of these places, it means you are <vocabulary>to be discharged</vocabulary>.

An <kanji>early</kanji> <kanji>retreat</kanji> means that you <vocabulary>leave early</vocabulary>.

Note that 早退 means leaving school or work earlier than usual. It's not used for leaving hangouts or parties early.

If you're on a <kanji>route</kanji>, right in the <kanji>middle</kanji>, you're <vocabulary>on the way</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>en route</vocabulary>.

途中 can also be used figuratively to say you're <vocabulary>in the middle of</vocabulary> doing something or something is <vocabulary>half done</vocabulary>.
Remember how 逮捕 is an "arrest" or "capture"? This is the verb version, and it is <vocabulary>to arrest</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to capture</vocabulary>.

Ugh, that <kanji>field</kanji> <kanji>guy</kanji>. He's the worst. Always in the fields, making us look bad, quite the <vocabulary>bastard</vocabulary>. Really though, he's just this guy, but for some reason I sometimes don't like him.

While 野郎 can be a casual term for a man, it's usually used to insult or show annoyance towards someone. So it's best to avoid using it unless you're really sure it's okay!
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
What's <kanji>below</kanji> your <kanji>shoes</kanji>? Your <vocabulary>socks</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>shoes</kanji> <kanji>shop</kanji> is one that sells shoes. It's a <vocabulary>shoe store</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>shoe shop</vocabulary>.

<kanji>Long</kanji> <kanji>shoes</kanji> aren't long in that the feet part are long (that wouldn't make sense). Instead, the top part is long to keep you dry when it's raining. Yes, these are <vocabulary>rain boots</vocabulary>.

In modern Japanese, 長靴 is most commonly used to mean rain boots or <vocabulary>rubber boots</vocabulary>. It can occasionally mean <vocabulary>riding boots</vocabulary> as well. But if you're referring to fashion boots or boots in general, you can just call them ブーツ.
影響 is "influence," so an <kanji>evil</kanji> <kanji>influence</kanji> is a <vocabulary>bad influence</vocabulary>.

隠居 is "retirement". Make that a verb and you have <vocabulary>to retire</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to be retired</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to go into retirement</vocabulary>.

Like 隠居, this word emphasizes life after retiring, and usually implies having a quiet, maybe secluded, lifestyle. It's a bit of an old-fashioned word, but you'll still see it in modern writing.

An <kanji>alive</kanji> <kanji>alcohol</kanji> <kanji>shop</kanji> is a place that serves a lot of alcohol. In Japan, these places are often <vocabulary>izakaya</vocabulary>. If you don't already know what an izakaya is, you can consider it to be a casual <vocabulary>Japanese Style Bar</vocabulary>.

An izakaya is a pub or tavern where you can enjoy drinks and tasty bar food like yakitori and gyoza, usually at quite affordable prices. Cheers!
比較 is <vocabulary>comparison</vocabulary>. So, verb version of that? It's <vocabulary>to compare</vocabulary>.

The <kanji>bathe</kanji> <kanji>clothes</kanji> are clothes you wear to and from the bath. They're your <vocabulary>yukata</vocabulary>.

浴衣 originated as robes worn in a steam bath (that explains the kanji), but these days people mostly wear them at summer festivals or traditional Japanese inns. Be careful not to mix up 浴衣 with 着物, which are much more formal and elaborate!

To <kanji>support</kanji> yourself to some <kanji>degree</kanji>, you need <vocabulary>preparation</vocabulary>. Doing your hair and makeup in the morning supports your presentation to some extent, right? 

This is another word for "preparation" besides 準備 and 用意. They’re all similar, but 支度 is usually used in personal contexts, such as 身支度 (getting dressed) or 旅支度 (<vocabulary>getting ready</vocabulary> for a trip).

A room that comes <kanji>alive</kanji> in <kanji>interval</kanji>s is your <vocabulary>living room</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>sitting room</vocabulary>. You don't spend all your time in there, so it can only be alive sometimes.

Note that 居間 is a little old-fashioned. These days, the more common word for a living room is リビングルーム.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>yield</kanji>, and 屈む means <vocabulary>to bend down</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to crouch</vocabulary>. After all, bending down and crouching are sort of like yielding to gravity, don’t you think?

屈む refers to the act of lowering your head or body, so it can also mean <vocabulary>to duck</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to squat</vocabulary> depending on the context.

When you <kanji>pull</kanji> yourself back and <kanji>retreat</kanji>, you're <vocabulary>retiring</vocabulary>. At some point in everyone's lives you just can't do it anymore and it's time to take your <vocabulary>retirement</vocabulary>.

This word focuses on the moment of retiring. It's often used to mean <vocabulary>withdrawing from public life</vocabulary>, when someone ends their career in a particular field, like when celebrities or pro athletes retire. It can also be used for students who stop extracurricular activities like clubs and sports teams ahead of graduation, often to study for their exams.
Remember how you learned that 渡す means "to hand over?" Well you can use your actual <kanji>hand</kanji> <vocabulary>to hand over</vocabulary> something too!

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>long for</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to long for</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>to yearn after</vocabulary>.

<kanji>Reason</kanji> <kanji>yield</kanji>s to <vocabulary>logic</vocabulary> and more <vocabulary>reasoning</vocabulary>.

理屈 can be neutral, but it often has negative connotations too, like when it refers to an <vocabulary>argument</vocabulary> that contains questionable logic, pretexts, or too much pedantry.

The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

Just keep in mind 胃 is specifically for the internal organ "stomach," not for the general abdominal area "stomach."

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.

The kanji itself means <kanji>obey</kanji>, but the verb meaning is a bit different. In most contexts, it often just means <vocabulary>to be accompanied by</vocabulary> someone or <vocabulary>to have in tow</vocabulary>. To help you remember this, imagine that everyone you're accompanied by obeys you! You're sort of their leader, so you go everywhere with them following in tow.

従える is a relatively formal word that's often used in literature.

auxiliary_meanings.meaning: Leaving A Decision To Someone Else

meaning_mnemonic:
This word comes from 任せる, but without the る on the end it's a noun. You also have the honorific お on the beginning, which is a clue that you're addressing someone else. So you're entrusting something to the person you're talking to, and this means <vocabulary>leaving decisions to someone else</vocabulary>. This is used a lot in restaurants, where it means <vocabulary>chef's choice</vocabulary> or simply <vocabulary>omakase</vocabulary>. In other words, you're leaving the choice of food to the chef.

It can be used in other contexts, too, like if you leave your haircut up to your stylist or a flower arrangement up to the florist, or even if you follow the recommended program at the gym.

Remember 主観的 meaning "subjective"? This is the counterpart to that. And since <kanji>guest</kanji>s' and customers' <kanji>view</kanji>s are always objectively right, this means <vocabulary>objective</vocabulary>.
To <kanji>unite</kanji> as <kanji>one</kanji> is to achieve total <vocabulary>unity</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>uniformity</vocabulary>.

Turn <kanji>expense</kanji> into a verb and you get <vocabulary>to spend</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to expend</vocabulary>. Or, in some cases, <vocabulary>to waste</vocabulary>.

In addition to spending money, 費やす can be used to refer to spending other resources like time, effort, energy, and emotions.

The kanji means <kanji>respond</kanji>, and this is also <vocabulary>to respond to</vocabulary>, but often in the sense of trying <vocabulary>to meet</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to live up to</vocabulary> some expectation, need, or other feelings.

Check out our common word combinations and context sentences for some example usages of this!

You have <kanji>hand</kanji> and the noun version of 拭く (to wipe). Put the two together and you get a <vocabulary>hand wipe</vocabulary>!

お手拭き refers to a <vocabulary>wet hand towel</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>wet napkin</vocabulary> used for cleaning your hands, often provided at restaurants in Japan before a meal.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means renew, but the verb meaning is a little different. This means to grow late, to wear on, or to deepen. Think of it this way: you only renew stuff that's not new, after time has worn on a bit — your streaming subscriptions, your driver's license, your marriage vows. And with each renewal you feel the passage of time a little more deeply… You'll see 更ける more often in writing, usually in reference to night or autumn, as in 夜が更ける (the night grows late) and 秋が更ける (autumn deepens).
